titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Albert Osborn family papers 1977.563
titlestmt.author: Nicholas Pavlik
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-08-21 11:14:41 +0000.

did.abstract: This collection consists of correspondence between Albert Osborn and his daughter, Anna, regarding her schoolwork and his travels to California and Mexico during the period 1849 to 1852. Also included is a legal agreement between Albert Osborn and Samuel Smith for a plot of land on Gallatin Place in Brooklyn, as well as various financial notes and the last will and testament of Adeline Osborn. Albert and Adeline Osborn lived with their daughter Anna on Gallatin Place in Brooklyn, N.Y., on a plot of land between Fulton and Livingston Streets that Albert had purchased in 1856.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Minimally processed to the collection level.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Mrs. Malcolm G. Smith, date unknown. Formally accessioned in 1977.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Albert and Adeline Osborn lived with their daughter Anna on Gallatin Place in Brooklyn, N.Y., on a plot of land between Fulton and Livingston Streets that Albert had purchased in 1856. During Albert's time living in California in the late 1840s and early 1850s, Adeline and Anna had resided at No. 20 Johnson Street in Brooklyn.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Albert Osborn family papers, 1977.563, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of correspondence between Albert Osborn and his daughter, Anna, regarding her schoolwork and his travels to California and Mexico during the period 1849 to 1852. Also included is a legal agreement between Albert Osborn and Samuel Smith for a plot of land on Gallatin Place in Brooklyn, as well as various financial notes and the last will and testament of Adeline Osborn.
